author: T79
title: Odd one out
review:
Another oldie, this is one I actually remember having played with and it's a rather unique entry in the 'building set with people' theme.

Box/Instructions

I never had the box, and the instructions have been long lost. I can't even remember I had them so maybe it came built when it was handed down?

Parts

There are some very unique parts here: the red maxifig head and hands, the headdress with feather (which, amazingly, survived the ravages of time and eager children) and the black mirror as paddle (which, sadly, did not). Even a red minifig head (without print) and a black pigtail hairdo!

Minifigures

Maxifigures, really, unless you count the papoose as half a minifig. Standard fare constructed maxifigs with the unique twist that these are red instead of standard yellow. Early lego racial profiling? The way the minifig is used to represent a baby is very clever, even though the slightest touch makes mama tip over backwards.

The build

Easy as can be, really. Most of this is also the maxifigures, the canoe contains but a small fraction of the bricks included in this set.

The completed model

A pair of Indians in a canoe with another pair on the shore. Like all lego of that time it is (exceedingly) simple but recognizable. There's not much to play with here though, you can move the canoe and have the others wave as it passes by. It could be more fun alongside #210 Cowboys, but I never had that one nor was I ever aware it existed until recently.

Overall opinion

If it weren't for the unique angle this wouldn't have received four stars as overall rating, but since this is the only Indian set in the 'building set with people' theme it receives extra points for being special. This must have been one of the last western themed sets (there were some with those early minifigs) until, well, 'western' in 1996.

author: BrickbyBrickDFM
title: Homemakers Set 215 - American Indian
review:
I was excited when I purchased this set from eBay for a reasonable price. As a person of color and a LEGO collector I have been trying to collect sets that include diverse figures. 

However, at the same time I am also conscious of certain images that reinforce negative stereotypes regarding American Indians.  The 1977 Homemakers LEGO set 215 could be viewed as controversial in today's climate. During the time of this review, America finds itself dealing with racial tensions, particularly with sport team's mascots and the impact of COVID-19 on American Indian reservations. This pressure has eventually caused Daniel Snyder, owner of the Washington Football Team to reevaluate the name, logo, and mascot of the organization.  

So, as I write this review I will try not to be biased by historical and racial issues. The build itself was fun. For being a smaller set, the number of maxifugures exceeded my expectations.  The set has a total of 93 pieces (4 maxifugures and one minifigure). The set can be built into a canoe or other items, like a camp fire, native totem, etc... Other than these couple of small builds, this set really doesn't have much playable features.  

What excites me the most is having the original box. The box art is so elegant look of the past, which is so nostalgic of basic building experiences.  As an AFOL I see this as more of a collector's design piece to be displayed.
